{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3243418,"name":"Justin | 6925 Alumentor","username":"BTYWAR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/btywar/{size}/191771_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T20:56:28.021Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone, this is my first year doing programming, and I am the sole programmer on our team. I have been a mechanical member in previous years however I was forced to step up to this role due to a lack of programmers. Right now I am trying to program the wrist for our arm which is attached below.

Screen Shot 2023-10-20 at 4.57.34 PM1160×1550 304 KB

However, I am having trouble adjusting the speed. This is the code I currently have for the wrist subsystem:

Screen Shot 2023-10-20 at 4.45.59 PM1794×1700 177 KB

Screen Shot 2023-10-20 at 4.47.39 PM1640×814 94.2 KB

I have been changing the output value in: wristMotor.set(ControlMode.PercentOutput, 0.01);

I tried 0.1 initially and then kept decreasing until 0.01 but there was no visible decrease in speed. here is a video of the arm with the current code. Does anyone have any suggestions on how I can lower the speed? Thanks!

github

Google Drive","clicks":20},{"url":"https://github.com/BTYWAR/WA-2","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - BTYWAR/WA-2","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/b/4/b4caa4f93ffbfd244baf40f19fe48fe48ee1f2ed.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/3/c3bc713325e4bbfebd26cdf38307b90460776e5b.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/8/58e6c5bec9a91e9e0b82f4a21927d6dadee05551.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56061,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-set-position-programming-help/442804/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3243430,"name":"Harry Chen","username":"HarryXChen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/harryxchen/{size}/199841_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T21:16:24.270Z","cooked":"

The behavior in the video looks like its actually trying to hold a position instead of being in PercentOutput, could you share where you are actually calling SwingArmOff()? (or runWristF(), you didn’t specify) In particular, are you sure you aren’t calling any of the other methods like runToBasePosition() or wirstZero() which try to run the motor to a position?

If you have your code publicly posted somewhere (like on github), sharing that would be very helpful!

Hi, here is the github: GitHub - BTYWAR/WA-2
Yes, I am trying to set a position and have it hold it there, but I want to change the speed it takes to get there.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-10-20T21:42:11.612Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":54.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":442804,"topic_slug":"arm-set-position-programming-help","display_username":"Justin | 6925 Alumentor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/BTYWAR/WA-2","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - BTYWAR/WA-2","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":59202,"username":"HarryXChen","name":"Harry Chen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/harryxchen/{size}/199841_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56061,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-set-position-programming-help/442804/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3243509,"name":"Harry Chen","username":"HarryXChen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/harryxchen/{size}/199841_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-21T01:38:13.274Z","cooked":"

Ok, so when you specify a ControlMode when calling .set(), that changes how the motor controller (in this case the TalonFX) behaves and how it interprets the value you give it in the 2nd argument.

The TalonFX can only be in a single control mode at 1 time, which means when you call set(ControlMode.Position, 0), it will put the controller into positional control mode, but when you then call set(ControlMode.PercentOutput, 0), that will put the controller into percent output (duty cycle) mode.

If you are calling set(Position, {any number}), it will override the last set(PercentOutput, {any number}) - I think you are trying to limit the max output/velocity while still controlling the mechanism through position, for that, you have a couple options -

There are 2 ways to limit the velocity/output of a motor in Phoenix 5, ideally, I would look into MotionMagic control, its the builtin method of using a trapezoidal profile/s-curve to limit your velocity and acceleration, or, you can config the nominalOutputForward and nominalOutputReverse params on the controller.

Alternatively, you can maybe use a TrapezoidalProfile from WPILIB, but might be hard to integrate with Phoenix 5 (you’d have to feed the position/velocity goals into the controller, and im not too sure if thats a good idea)

CTRE has some pretty decent examples on MotionMagic and closed-loop control on the TalonFX

  • MotionMagic
  • Position Closed-Loop

P.s. if possible I would recommend switching to Phoenix 6 (its free now), it comes with much more intuitive units and an overall more polished library (and very nice documentation)

Hello, thank you so much for the reply. I think I understand the error right now. It seems like nominalOutputForward is the easiest to use, however I am still unsure how to use it. The CTR site seems to say that you can configure it using the Tuner? If it is through the code, is there an example of how to use it? Thanks!

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-10-21T07:17:44.407Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":23.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":442804,"topic_slug":"arm-set-position-programming-help","display_username":"Justin | 6925 Alumentor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56061,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-set-position-programming-help/442804/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3243582,"name":"Harry Chen","username":"HarryXChen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/harryxchen/{size}/199841_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-21T11:45:05.271Z","cooked":"

I actually made a mistake, I meant to say peakOutputForward instead of nominalOutputForward, peak limits the maximum, nominal clamps/promotes the minimum. So if you want to limit the max output, you want to be using peakOutputForward and peakOutputReverse instead.

The Java API docs are here.

CTRE recommends that you use the configAll() API, so instead of doing config_kP(), config_kD, config_*(), they suggest that you use a TalonFXConfiguration object and then use configAll() to configurate all the settings

An example of how to do that is here

/* Factory Default all hardware to prevent unexpected behaviour */
talonFX.configFactoryDefault();

final TalonFXConfiguration config = new TalonFXConfiguration();
config.peakOutputForward = 0.5;  // [0, 1], 0 being no output allowed, 1 being full forward output
config.peakOutputReverse = -0.5;  // [-1, 0], 0 being no output allowed, -1 being full reverse output
config.slot0.kP = 0.2; // or whatever kP
config.slot0.kD = 0.2; // or whatever kD
// etc...

/* Configure the TalonFX with the TalonFXConfiguration object */
talonFX.configAllSettings(config);

The talonFX.configFactoryDefault(); does not seem to work. But, I think I implemented the rest of the changes. I updated the github, can you please take a look? Thanks!

Ok, taking a look at your code again I have a few things that you’d probably want to address

  • What editor (IDE) are you using? I’m not sure how you uploaded your code (was it by copy paste? or do you have a git repo?), but there are some formatting issues that when fixed, could lead you to figure out some of the issues you’re experiencing (I mention IDE because most IDEs can automatically format code for you)
  • I used talonFX in the code example as just a placeholder, it needs to be replaced by a reference to your motor, in this case, your wristMotor (you seem to have done it correctly for configAllSettings() but not for configFactoryDefault())
  • configFactoryDefault() should be called right before you configure your motor, i.e. right before you call configAllSettings(), It won’t even compile where you are current calling it.
  • I’m curious as to why you’re explicitly casting the wristMotor to a IMotorController by doing (IMotorController)wristMotor… there shouldn’t be a need to do that afaik.
","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-10-21T20:28:06.138Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":16.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442804,"topic_slug":"arm-set-position-programming-help","display_username":"Harry Chen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56061,"username":"BTYWAR","name":"Justin | 6925 Alumentor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/btywar/{size}/191771_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59202,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/arm-set-position-programming-help/442804/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3243705,"name":"Justin | 6925 Alumentor","username":"BTYWAR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/btywar/{size}/191771_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-21T21:02:25.235Z","cooked":"

I am using VScode, I am just straight up uploading the file from my computer into github. I think I fixed everything, I updated the github with the fixes. I casted the wristMotor to IMotorController earlier because it kept giving me errors and that was the suggestion it gave. I got rid of it now, and it works. Thank you so much!

Cool! Make sure you tune your PID(F) for your wrist to get a good response out of it, other than that (and the weird formatting), your code looks good!

If you could mark a reply as the solution, that would be great! (prevents other people from looking into an already solved problem)
